text: If we’re saying that our minds, language, and the world have a mysterious, strange-loopy correspondence/relationship with each other, I’m totally into it. But if we’re saying we can only have knowledge of our own minds, I must vehemently disagree. I can’t offer any proofs to the contrary - how do you prove to someone they are or are not trapped in the Matrix or Plato’s Cave? I happen to believe you can prove this, and that DesCartes did prove this, but I’m not an expert in that and won’t get into it here. What I can much more readily point out is the deleterious effects of this kind of radical idealism on human health and happiness, which, though not rigorous, may still be convincing. Consider what we mean when we say of a person “She’s lost touch with reality”, or, “He’s trapped inside his own head”. If all our knowledge is invention, if the only thing we discover is the convolutions of our own mind, the world grows both very small and very boring. A view of the most picturesque and expansive landscape is still just a view of the back of your eyeballs. Even the most stimulating conversations are only conversations with yourself.

text: And why is it _necessary_ that the world be nothing like our perceptions of it? What if there really are maps and sets and categories? Is that so impossible a notion? Does any of current knowledge demand the contrary?

text:
>Does any of current knowledge demand the contrary?

Yes. If you're looking for another rabbit hole to climb into, I can recommend George Lakoff's _Women, Fire, and Dangerous Things_. 

It just occurred to me, that a third of the book, part 2, is titled “Philosophical Implications” and might be relevant for this discussion (not so much for learning category theory ;-). 

It’s hard to summarize in a few sentences, but Lakoff presents a lot of evidence, both empirical as well as logical proof that Objectivist metaphysics and cognition (super-oversimplified: the notion that there is an external, independent reality/truth we are merely experiencing and modeling with thought and language) are not sufficient to create a theory of meaning.

Interestingly, Lakoff also goes into great depth that the usual reaction of people presented with that conclusion is to swing the pendulum too far to the other side, only accepting total Relativism then (similarly oversimplified: no objective, universal truth; everybody makes up their own) and then goes on to present an alternative model, Experientialism, which is what the book is about and super interesting, if you wonder how we can find a middle ground that gives us consistency to be able to communicate using consistent concepts, and yet still takes into account the fact that we are limited by our perception in physical, biological, environmental, sociological, and cultural ways.

I doubt that Milewski was alluding to any of that though and I feel like we definitely got on quite a tangent here.

attachments.title: Experientialism
attachments.text:
Experientialism is the philosophical theory that experience is the source of knowledge. It was originally formulated by George Lakoff and Mark Johnson and its first widely known formulation is to be found in the book Metaphors We Live By.
In Women, Fire and Dangerous Things, Lakoff has expanded on the foundation of experientialism by his research into the nature of categories.
